channel.title: Seminar Project in B. Bowe's Class
channel.description: Framing of the Salish Sea in the Seattle Times

item.title: Environmental Communication
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: Environmental Communication Environmental Communication is a field of communication specifically related to the environment, which is to say a field of news, public relations, activism, and dozens of other fields all interacting with each other to influence and inform the public. In order to cut through the noise that is often faced by communicators, they must employ strategies to effectively create change in modern societies. (Liang, 2018.) These strategies could be applied to areas of environmental crisis which “require strategic messaging to mobilize the masses to engage in pro-environmental behaviors.” As Liang points out, many environmental communicators are simply going with their “personal intuitions” when it comes to their efforts. They often use “individual preferences, and imitations of existing campaigns” to complete their goals. Liang et al. describe these communication practices as SEC, or Strategic Environmental Communication. This will form the basis for an example of how environmental communicators influence each other and practitioners of news media to portraying their worldview in the same way they see it. Liang describes SEC as different from normal strategic communication in that “SEC harnesses strategic communication to promote pro-environmental causes and/or behaviors with goals that benefit the larger society rather than the sole organization.” (Liang, 2018) This is contrasted with strategic communication, wherein the goals and endeavors of a single organization are the focus, whether that’s financial gain or simple marketing. The strategies employed by environmental communicators include providing information in raw data, pictorial forms, or they imply some kind of consequences, or they do some of both of the above, but with a positive and suggesting tone. Liang describes these three methods as ED, LA, and CT, in relation to the testing environmental issue, droughts. See Fig. 1. Liang found that “the LA (implied consequences) strategy generally increases reactance; albeit the effects are reduced when an ED (Raw data) strategy occurs simultaneously. There is also a CT (Suggestive tone) main effect and a three-way interaction among all three strategies that approaches statistical significance. These findings document that water conservation messages generate reactance .For SEC, it is important to note that well-intended water conservation messages can produce the opposite effect when messages convey a sense of loss because they induce psychological reactance among receivers. However, messages containing CT generally reduce reactance. In other words, strategic environmental messages would avoid generating psychological reactance that can boomerang.” Because of these results, environmental communication, while a fairly new and ever-more omnipresent field, often is limited by the way communicators can send out messages. “messages that can enhance a receiver’s sense of personal freedom and minimize a threat to personal freedom are preferable. For example, a water conservation campaign practitioner can design messages that promote water conservation as a voluntary choice or a lifestyle a receiver can choose to adopt. A practitioner should consider avoiding messages that communicate to a receiver in a demanding, controlling, or moralizing way, that s/he must conserve water.” To that end, in a search for messages from environmental communicators, one should look for messages that enhance a person’s sense of personal freedom, such as “you can help save the whales,” for example. Such a message, contrasted with “whales are crucial to the Salish Sea’s ecosystem and we have to save them” would have a distinctively decreased effect on a reader, so communicators and users of SEC will be less likely to use them.

item.title: Methods
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded:
What Media Outlet: The Seattle Times Time Range: two years on either side of the U.S. Government's ratification of the "Salish Sea" and an equivalent number of articles from the most recent published. Content: Environmental stories, or stories that affect the environment (not events calendars) How much content: Recent articles, and the two years on either side of the ratification of the Salish Sea name in WA and B.C. Governments (42 of each, totaling 84) Accessibility: Through a NewsBank inc. search, on the Seattle Times (Seattle Times, The (WA)) Archive, with 361 results for “Salish Sea” as of 3/5/2020 Analysis: The content of these articles will be analyzed through a content analysis, supporting a more qualitative analysis. The sourcing and topic of the articles will provide a basis for showing common frames, such as ecological crisis, business, travel, government, innovation, accident, etc., in a more qualitative analysis. Additionally, the word usage of each of the stories will be summarized and evaluated over time, looking for keywords in environmental stories to develop a framework of commonly used techniques for influencing articles.   Code Sheet:
General Ecology Ecological Crisis Business Travel Gov’t Innovation Accident ???
Gov’t off.
Tribes
Business int’s.
Activists
Scientists
PR People
???
  Textual Analysis: In order to analyze a frame, it must first be deconstructed, so while analyzing I will define common frames, using keywords and the correlation of sources and article subject.

item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Conclusions
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: 2008-2012 The first 42 articles analyzed showed that the term Salish Sea was predominantly used in Environmentally focused articles, with Lynda Mapes as the primary reporter, in a news context, most often contacting government officials for stories involving the government or ecological crises. Activists and Scientists were both peaks for ecology and environmental crises. Often, the most common word was “name,” showing that in the articles analyzed, the name is still an uncertain topic and needs to be explained as a name for the region. As more data are added, this will likely change. Another peak word was Fish, for obvious reasons when discussing the Salish Sea, fish are likely to come up. Recent Articles (42 stories, ~1 year since time of analysis.) In the 42 most recent articles, trends were similar but different. A wider variety of sources were contacted per story, stories were primarily focused around whales or fish, while usage of the term "salish sea" went up as a whole. The decrease in coverage variety is likely due to the decreased ability of the Seattle Times to cover all types of stories in the area, or that the term Salish Sea is limiting to news stories. This would be supported by the two distinct peaks in authors, Evan Bush and Lynda V Mapes being the two primary sources in the last 42 articles and ~1 year to use "Salish Sea" in their stories, rather than all Seattle Times staff when referring to the area. Others are likely using more micro scale references, like the names of cities and towns. Qualitative analysis: In the 2008-2012 article, the term “Salish Sea” is still relatively unknown and is explained to the reader, but as time continues, the frequency of explanations seems to be decreasing, as well as the term “Salish Sea just becoming more common. In the two years on either side of 2012, there were approximately 60 responses, including several duplicate articles and events pages, which were excluded from analysis. In the two most recent years from March 2020, there were 101 results. In three years, 132. In the most recent 4 years, 140 results from Newsweb’s archive. This shows that the term Salish Sea is rising in casual news usage. The 2008-2012 data also showed that newswriters were most likely to contact government officials and scientists significantly more frequently for topics of ecology and crisis than tribal resources, for example. In the articles analyzed, scientists were never contacted for business-related stories. This is supported by the modern data, but the trend is disappearing. Tribal and First Nations representatives were contacted more and more often for each story in the modern era. Overall, more sources seemed to be contacted for a wider variety of stories. Conclusion Inquiry Question: “How does the Seattle Times frame and source news stories about the Salish Sea?” Thesis Statement: The term "The Salish Sea" is used in the Seattle Times significantly more frequently than it has in the past, and usage is becoming associated with a wider variety of stories and sources,in wider variety of frames.

item.title: Introduction
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: Framing of the Salish Sea in the Seattle Times The purpose of this project is to show how issues facing the Salish Sea are framed in the Seattle Times, using an analysis of the article’s sourcing and common frames. “How does the Seattle Times frame and source news stories about the Salish Sea?” The Seattle Times is a well-reputed newspaper in the Pacific Northwest. They are often the first group to cover new and arising issues facing the Salish Sea region, and as such can set the tone for later coverage.[1] The term “Salish Sea” itself is comparatively recent. It has been internationally accepted for use as of 2010 but has been in casual use since 1988. It is not intended to be a replacement for the names “Puget Sound,” “Georgia Strait,” or the “Strait of Juan de Fuca,” but is instead intended to be an umbrella term for the three, indicating the transboundary nature of the Salish Sea.[2] The Seattle Times has been covering The Salish Sea using that title in many published articles since the early 2010’s but was more often used in conjunction with the terms “Puget Sound” or “Georgia Strait.”[3] Since then, use of the term has only increased.[4] This project will be about the language use when the Salish Sea is a news topic. There are several contexts in which it might appear. These could include stories like Orca deaths/decline, salmon recovery issues, oil shipping, vessel noise, pollution, which could largely be called “ecological crisis” stories. Additional topics that might come up are general ecological stories, business stories, travel stories, government stories, technological innovations, accidents or more. Correlating the stories with the sources typically contacted for each type of story will give a sense of how the Salish Sea is being posed to the general public. Is it something to be protected, is it independent, is it outside of the average person’s purview? Who decides those things? An example series of articles could be Lynda Mapes’ recent “Hostile Waters: Orcas in Peril” series, which frames the Southern Resident Killer Whales in a very “perilous” light, through their use of scientific sources and ecological crisis frame, rather than a frame of travel, for example.[5] For many people, the Seattle Times might be the only source of information about the Salish Sea, and so they might only ever see anything about the term when something is going poorly or very well. This project may very well also illuminate how people see the Salish Sea as a place to live. Your average resident of the Salish Sea is not going to seek out the annual Puget Sound Partnership State of the Sound report[6] to find out what issues are facing their home. They will likely only google something like “salish sea issues”[7] or “problems facing the salish sea”[8] or perhaps “what is the salish sea.”[9] The types of language that they encounter in the articles that they find will likely help them to form opinions about the Salish Sea, and through analysis of the language used we may be able to find how the average citizen perceives the Salish Sea. The project will be limited by articles published by the Seattle Times, about the Salish Sea, and about topics of concerning the Salish Sea, either positive or negative. Narrowing the timeframe to the areas around the development of the name “The Salish Sea,” and modern day will give some ideas about how the framing and sourcing has changed over time, or not. Determining the frame will be a normative analysis, but will serve as a platform for a further analysis. [1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9yFENr7ABcc [2] https://wp.wwu.edu/salishsea/description-of-the-salish-sea/ [3] https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/state-board-adds-salish-sea-to-regions-watery-lexicon/ [4] https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?cat=14&date=all&q=Salish%20Sea [5] https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/hostile-waters-orcas-killer-whale-puget-sound-washington-canada/ [6] https://www.psp.wa.gov/sos.php [7] https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-1-d&q=salish+sea+issues [8] https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-1-d&q=problems+facing+the+salish+sea [9] https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-1-d&q=What+is+the+salish+sea

Sol Hart. “Broadening Exposure to Climate Change News? How Framing and Political Orientation Interact to Influence Selective Exposure.” Journal of Communication 68, no. 3 (June 1, 2018): 503–24. https://doi.org/10.1093/joc/jqy011. Chong, Dennis, and James N. Druckman. “Framing Theory.” Annual Review of Political Science 10, no. 1 (May 4, 2007): 103–26. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev.polisci.10.072805.103054. Figure 1:

item.title: The Salish Sea
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: Salish Sea The Salish Sea region (USGS, 2020) is a rapidly growing, urban, forested, riparian, mountainous, natural area, with dozens of other adjectives to describe it. There are always more and more people interested in communicating issues faced by the people, creatures and environment in the Salish Sea. As such, there should be some consistent way in which communicators are sharing this information, likely through news sources, such as the Seattle Times. The name “Salish Sea” itself was coined in 1988, by Bert Webber (Webber, 2019) and has persisted as a way to describe the transboundary nature of the region. An umbrella term, meant to describe the waters of the Puget Sound, Strait of Juan de Fuca and the Strait of Georgia. The term was inherently political, crossing the Canadian/American border, and using the name of a local group of tribes. Over the next ~20 years, Webber worked to get the name into common parlance, accepted by tribes and governments, and by 2010, the name “Salish Sea” was officially adopted by Canadian, tribal, and U.S. governments. The effect of having a border between a significant geological feature is powerful, especially for those who the border is comparatively new, which should be taken into account in any discussion of the Salish Sea region. “The production of divergent political systems in Canada and the US affected and continues to affect environmental governance – particularly access to, and management of, resources – for indigenous communities... the political demarcation not only severed a cultural continuum that spanned and predated the 49th parallel, but it also created different national identities, rights to ownership of land, and land and resource policies that continue to impact indigenous communities" (Boxberger, 1989; Harris, 2000, 2001, 2002). "As the divergent political systems strengthened and developed national identities, indigenous communities, whose traditional territory spanned the international divide, became increasingly fragmented.” (Norman, 2012.) This name is comparatively new, so many articles published by groups like the Seattle Times will likely be using the terms Puget Sound, Strait of Georgia or Strait of Juan de Fuca to talk about the water region. As such, the search terms “Salish Sea” produces only 456 results on the Seattle Times website, compared to ~20,000 with the term “Puget Sound,” 146 for “Strait of Georgia,” and 1212 for “Strait of Juan de Fuca.” (Seattle Times, 2/9/20) This limitations on the searchable material will provide useful information for how articles relating to the Salish Sea are framed, sourced, and reported.

item.title: Environmental Issues
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: Environmental Issues Environmental issues are inherently non-sexy. As such, reporting coverage often fluctuates, from high intensity debate to subdued activism, a study out of Sweden suggests that this could be caused by the dynamic interaction of news topics over time, making it not so much a constant flood, as more of a tide. This study is called issue dynamics, “Issue dynamics mean that reporting on one issue influences coverage of other issues... Research on issue dynamics so far, however, has been surprisingly scant both in environmental studies and in journalism studies at large. Thus we do not know whether, for instance, the intense coverage of climate change in recent years has contributed to an increase in the attention paid to other environmental issues, or if climate change has occupied so much of the available news space that all other issues are crowded out.” (Djerf-Pierre, 2012) Djerf-Pierre also proposes a useful guideline in the same paper, that “Any research aimed at studying environmental journalism must depart from the premise that there are some issues and topics that can be defined as ‘environmental’," but as Reese (2001: 8) argues, the "‘tendency to classify issues into categories . . . obscures the important questions of how they are defined in the first place’." "Clearly, not all environmental problems become issues in the news and once they do they also tend to evolve and change. Accordingly, the environment can be perceived of as a dynamic issue domain, comprising several sub-domains of equally changeable issues, and the scope and boundaries of the domain are always contested.” (Djerf-Pierre, 2012) This is a useful idea, because of the ever-changing facts of the environment, a report must be also ever changing, which influences it’s dynamic acceptance among the populace. Djerf-Pierre suggests that not all environmental stories are environmentally framed, and vice versa, so they define environmental news as “news that is framed as to concern the negative impact or the risk of such an impact of human activities on the natural world, but also all the societal processes and activities addressing these problems…” That is a reasonable working definition for environmental news, which reports upon environmental issues. Djerf-Pierre finds in the article that the ability of viewers (as judged by producers setting story times on broadcast television in Sweden) oscillates between extreme interest, and extreme disinterest. “There is indeed a positive correlation between different environmental issues with regard to the level of attention. An intense focus on one category of environmental issues does not crowd out all other environmental concerns in the news. On the contrary, a surge in interest for one category of environmental problems generates attention to other environmental issues as well.” (Djerf-Pierre, 2012)

item.title: Environmental Framing
item.dc:creator: meachac
item.content:encoded: Environmental Framing “Research suggests that changing the frame, or lens, through which climate change is interpreted can impact public opinion and behavior” (e.g., Hart, 2011; Myers, Nisbet, Maibach, & Leiserowitz, 2012). Yet, these studies assume that people will be exposed to messages about climate change in the first place; this may not be the case, and frames found to be effective in experimental studies may offer limited value if individuals don’t pay attention to them in the real world.” (Feldman, 2018) Feldman’s article touches on the ideas that people don’t like to be dissuaded from their preconceptions, so an important facet of determining how environmental communicators share ideas is, are people willing to accept them? Feldman points out that individuals are selective of what news they choose to spend time consuming, and their choice is typically news that is in line with what they already know/believe, and they actively avoid dissonant information. There are partisan divides, but also preferred news types, Feldman points out. So, how do frames “schemata of interpretation,” influence news coverage? Well, when the only options for news are about climate in Feldman’s study, “experiments indicate that a public health frame holds some advantage for increasing exposure to climate change news,” and in another study, where climate stories were placed alongside other general news stories, the frames did not have any significant effect at all. Overall, frames influencing public health resonated well with all audiences, so it will be interesting to see if environmental stories contain a public health frame, as opposed to “national security, economic, or morality dimensions of climate change.” (Feldman, 2018)
